message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Standard translations all use "virtue" for 德 — reconsider?">
New data for the 德 discussion. The passage 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼 (Dao De Jing Ch. 38) has well-established standard English translations:

**D.C. Lau**: "When the way was lost there was virtue; when virtue was lost there was benevolence; when benevolence was lost there was rectitude; when rectitude was lost there were the rites."

**Wing-tsit Chan**: "When the Way is lost, only then do we have virtue; when virtue is lost, only then do we have humanity; when humanity is lost, only then do we have righteousness; when righteousness is lost, only then do we have propriety."

**James Legge**: "When the Tao was lost, its attributes appeared; when its attributes were lost, benevolence appeared; when benevolence was lost, righteousness appeared; when righteousness was lost, the proprieties appeared."

Every major translator uses "virtue" for 德 in this passage. Our decision was "(constitutive) character" instead.

Given this data — does this change your view? Should we:
A) Keep "(constitutive) character" — our reasoned departure from tradition, acknowledged in TN
B) Use the standard "virtue" for the Laozi block quote specifically (since it IS a quotation of a classical text), then switch to "(constitutive) character" when the author begins their own analysis
C) Something else?

Brief response with your recommendation.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**Recommendation: B — use "virtue" in the Laozi block quote, then "(constitutive) character" in the author's analysis.**

This is not a compromise; it is the principled answer. Here is why:

When the author block-quotes 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼, the reader is encountering **Laozi's text**, not the author's text. The translation of the quotation should render Laozi as Laozi is standardly rendered. Every literate English reader who has encountered the Daodejing knows this passage with "virtue." Using "(constitutive) character" inside the Laozi quotation would create a jarring disconnect from the entire existing English-language tradition of this text -- the reader would not recognize the passage.

Then, when the author steps out of the quotation and begins their own analysis -- redefining 德 in constructivist terms -- the shift to "(constitutive) character" becomes **the translation performing the author's philosophical move**. The reader sees "virtue" in Laozi, then sees the author deliberately reframing it as "character." The change in terminology *enacts* the interpretive departure. This is more powerful than using our term throughout, because it makes visible what the author is doing to the tradition.

**Format:**

> Block quote: "When the Way was lost there was virtue; when virtue was lost there was humaneness..." (standard translation)

Author's analysis: "The author reconceives 德 not as virtue in the moral sense but as (constitutive) character (德, *De*) — the constitutive quality that makes a thing what it is..."

> Running text thereafter: "character"

This also establishes a general principle: **in classical block quotes, use standard established translations; in the author's own voice, use our dictionary terms.** This is consistent with our 文言 format convention and with making the classical/modern boundary visible through more than just formatting.
